Due to the rise in #COVID19 cases, CA is issuing a limited Stay at Home Order.

Non-essential work and gatherings must stop from 10pm-5am in counties in the purple tier.

This will take effect at 10pm on Saturday and remain for 1 month.

Together--we can flatten the curve again.

Voting in person? Protect yourself and others by following these simple guidelines:
‚Ä¢ Wear a face covering
‚Ä¢ Practice physical distancing in line and at voting booths
‚Ä¢ Bring hand sanitizer

During this heat wave, please make sure to drink water, stay indoors, and check on your neighbors and loved ones. Limit use of major appliances during peak hours to help conserve energy. 

You can find heat safety tips, cooling center locations & more at http://Emergency.LACity.org/Heat

Extreme record breaking temps and energy demand has caused some equip to overload and power outages this evening.  We have approx 14k customers without power out of 1.5 million.  If you are one of them, be assured our crews are responding and working to restore your power.

What we need is a real eviction moratorium for the extent of the public health crisis. If it‚Äôs unsafe for kids to go to school, why is it safe to evict them?

Evictions & displacement spread COVID-19. #AB3088 does not do enough to keep Californians safe. 3/3

In 2017 alone, the top 1% of California households collectively received over $340 billion. This is more than 10 times the income needed to lift every Californian above the poverty line.

It's time for a wealth tax in California.

During #COVID19, the gap is widening. Between March and June of this year, the 20 richest Californians saw their net worth grow by 30% - $111 BILLION - while a quarter of working people in California went unemployed - most of them people of color.

Today I introduced a Resolution in support of 
@SantiagoAD53
's AB 1253 to increase taxes for Californians who earn over $1 million in income. 

This would get more resources for essential services and vulnerable Californians at a time when it's most needed.

The Multipurpose Senior Services Program provides at-home living assistance to Medi-Cal seniors, and CA is debating cutting funding entirely. 

MSSP saves money, and keeps seniors out of nursing homes, which are especially dangerous during the pandemic.

Here's what you can do:

Call your State rep & the Governor and tell them that we should not be eliminating programs that keep seniors safe: 
@CAgovernor
: (916) 445-2841
Find your State rep: http://findyourrep.legislature.ca.gov

Here in Los Angeles, we've been calling for the preservation of this essential program. I introduced legislation officially opposing proposed budget cuts to the MSSP.

We don‚Äôt have to live like this. We don‚Äôt have to choke our city with pollution. We definitely don‚Äôt all need to commute to an office each day.

I have spent years getting our City moving in a more sustainable and healthy way - it‚Äôs time to rethink how we move altogether.

Today, I introduced a motion to rethink how we work & commute.
This legislation includes incentives for telecommuting& work from home for business, and a study on the costs of air pollution.

We can build a healthier LA, we just need to reimagine how we move and work.

We have learned a lot since the start of the Coronavirus pandemic.

One of them - LA can learn to live without air pollution and standstill traffic.

The U.S. is the global epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic. 

That could have been avoided, and countless lives could have been saved, if we had a President that was remotely competent.

The 1st of the month is here, and I want to make sure renters know their rights. There are protections in place - but we need more. 

I‚Äôm fighting for rent & mortgage forgiveness, because we are not meeting this crisis if we don‚Äôt provide direct help to people hurting most.

What we NEED is you to stop political grandstanding. You represent EVERYBODY in your district NOT JUST the tenants that are having a hard time. You have shown no balance of leadership, much less understanding of the outcome of your proposals.

Hi Bettershelter - we definitely want to help the small property owners who are hurting. That‚Äôs why I have called for rent & mortgage forgiveness - including on commercial property owners - from the beginning. We need relief for all Angelenos - not just big banks.

Replying to 
@davideryuResolution calling for Rent and Mortgage Forgiveness: This Resolution I have been calling for since April 1st seeks State and Federal action to suspend rents and mortgages during this crisis & give people some breathing room. (4/5)

Homelessness is an emergency. It's time we start acting like it.

Today, I introduced a motion to fundamentally change how we build homeless housing in LA. This motion would change how we identify, zone and build homeless housing and resources.PRESS RELEASE: Councilmember Ryu Calls for FEMA-like Response to Expedite Homeless Housing
davidryu.lacity.org

Our City was not designed to respond to a crisis of this size & scale. That's why we need to change the way our City works.

This motion would put temporary emergency powers in the Mayor's Office to zone, plan & build life-saving solutions to #homelessness wherever needed.

Despite all our efforts, homelessness is not getting better. 3 people a day are dying on our streets. The status quo is not sufficient to solve this crisis - we need a centralized, FEMA-like response.

This is is an emergency. Let's start acting like it.

Today we had a chance to advance real, wholesale change in City Hall. That‚Äôs not what happened.

JUST IN: 
@LACityCouncil
 unanimously approved my Moderate-Income Housing motion, so LA can finally start building more of the housing we need.

Right now, the largest share of Angelenos get the smallest share of housing. We need to flip that math -> http://bit.ly/2MBETmb

Replying to 
@davideryuMy motion does three things to fix this:
 Instructs City Planning to identify Los Angeles' middle class.
 Creates new incentives that spur more housing for this population.
 Prioritizes affordable & moderate-income housing in the permitting process.

LA is on track to meet its housing target set in 2013. But over 91% of that are luxury units.

Let's call this crisis what it is - an affordable housing crisis. Too many luxury units sit empty while everyone else is pushed to the margins. It's time to change how we build in LA.

Of those who fled the towers or the nearby destruction, 2,625 ‚Äî or about 12.3 percent of all survivors registered in the program ‚Äî have post-traumatic stress disorder.

‚ÄúPTSD doesn‚Äôt have a time limit.‚Äù https://nytimes.com/2019/09/11/nyregion/911-survivors-ptsd.html‚Ä¶

Remembering the tragic attacks that occurred 18 years ago today.

Most of all, thinking of the everyday heroes who rose up to save lives, the first responders who rushed into danger, and the survivors who continue to face mental and physical trauma. This is why we #NeverForget.

Chhovy Pich is a pop singer born in Tonle Bati, a farming village in Cambodia. During the Khmer Rogue, she was forced to leave her family behind, eventually immigrating to Long Beach with an adoptive father.

Singing was the bridge between her two lives.

Now a mom in California, Chhovy makes a point to connect her children with their Cambodian roots. 

‚ÄúI am very proud to be Cambodian. I want my kids to know who they are and where they come from.‚Äù #AAPI #HearMeRoar #APAHM

Today's #LACD4 historical pic comes from "The City Of Wonders" itself - Universal City! 
Opened by Carl Laemmle in 1915, Universal was the first film studio in the San Fernando Valley - and one of the first to let the public in to see the movie magic. #LAHistoryUniversal Pictures

It's true! 

From studio history (http://thestudiotour.com/ush/chronology.php‚Ä¶):
"Universal City had an official opening event on March 15, 1915. Carl Laemmle invited members of the public to watch films being made (for a 25 cents admission fee). A chicken lunch box was also available for a nickel."

It is the courage and wisdom of these men and women that made Korea free, and made my life, and the life of so many others, possible. 100 years later, we remember their sacrifice and owe them a great debt of gratitude. #Samiljeol 
#ÎåÄÌïúÎèÖÎ¶ΩÎßåÏÑ∏GIF

Today is a very important day for Korea and the Korean diaspora. On this day 100 years ago, a few brave young Koreans began the Korean Independence Movement - what became known as #Samiljeol, or the 3.1 Movement. A thread.

Replying to 
@davideryu"Our task today is to build up our own strength, not to destroy others," the declaration reads. "We must chart a new course for ourselves in accord with our solemn dictates of conscience, not malign and reject others for reasons of past enmity."
Despite this, many years of war and struggle followed. But the words of these brave Koreans held true, and Korea became a free nation in 1945.
